properties.title: UCL
properties.body:
From Always Coming Home by Ursula Le Guin (1985).

Always Coming Home is a science fiction novel written by Ursula Le Guin, one of the greatest writers on the question of utopia. The book purports to be an ‘archaeology’ of the Kesh, a people who live in an unspecified point in the far future in what is currently Northern California. Rather than presenting a conventional narrative, the novel is an assemblage of stories and anthropological observations made by ‘Pandora’, a visitor to this society, a stand-in for the author. The novel offers a number of paradoxical reflections on the relationship between the present and the future.

I found, at last, the town I had been hunting for. After digging in several wrong places for over a year and persisting in several blockheaded opinions--that it must be walled, with one gate, for instance--I was studying yet once more the contours of my map of the region, when it dawned as slowly and as certainly as the sun itself upon me that the town was there, between the creeks, under my feet the whole time. And there was never a wall; what on earth did they need a wall for? What I had taken for the gate was the bridge across the meeting of the creeks. And the sacred buildings and the dancing place not in the center of town, for the center is the Hinge, but over in their own arm of the double spiral, the right arm, of course--there in the pasture below the barn. And so it is, and so it is.

[...]

But I can't go digging there and hope to find the curved fragment of a roof tile, the iridescent foot of a wine goblet, the ceramic cap of a solar battery, or a little coin of the gold of California [...] I can walk in the wild oats and the thistles, between the houses of the little town I was looking for, Sinshan.

[...]

If I listen, can I hear voices with the inner ear? Could you hear voices, Schliemann, in the streets of Troy? If you did, you were crazy too. The Trojans had all been dead three thousand years. Which is farther from us, farther out of reach, more silent--the dead, or the unborn? Those whose bones lie under the thistles and the dirt and the tombstones of the Past, or those who slip weightless among molecules, dwelling where a century passes in a day, among the fair folk, under the great, bell-curved Hill of Possibility?

properties.title: Woburn Walk
properties.body:
From The Three Imposters; or, The Transmutations by Arthur Machen (1895).

Woburn Place was one of the first purpose-built shopping streets in London, the present shopfronts being constructed c. 1822. The most notable resident of the street was the Irish poet and mystic W. B. Yeats, who lived here between 1895-1919. During this period Yeats was a member of an occult society, the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn (also headquartered in Bloomsbury), whose membership included Moina Mathers, sister of Henri Bergson; the children’s author Edith Nesbit; and the ‘wickedest man in the world’, the occultist Aleister Crowley. Arthur Machen, a prolific writer of supernatural and horror fiction, was also a member. His collection of interlinked short stories, The Three Imposters, details a series of grisly crimes, all of which concern an enigmatic ‘young man in spectacles’ who bears a more than passing resemblance to Yeats. The following extract describes the moment in which Dyson, one of the protagonists of the stories, finally encounters the young man in a pub.

"Mr. Davies! For God's sake, have pity on me, Mr. Davies. On my oath, I say---" and his voice sank to silence as he heard the message, and strove in vain to bite his lip; and summon up to his aid some tinge of manhood. He stood there a moment, wavering as the leaves of an aspen, and then he was gone out into the street, as Dyson thought silently, with his doom upon his head. He had not been gone a minute when it suddenly flashed into Dyson's mind that he knew the man; it was undoubtedly the young man with spectacles for whom so many ingenious persons were searching; the spectacles indeed were missing, but the pale face, the dark whiskers, and the timid glances were enough to identify him. Dyson saw at once that by a succession of hazards he had unawares hit upon the scent of some desperate conspiracy, wavering as the track of a loathsome snake in and out of the highways and byways of the London cosmos; the truth was instantly pictured before him, and he divined that all unconscious and unheeding he had been privileged to see the shadows of hidden forms, chasing and hurrying, and grasping and vanishing across the bright curtain of common life, soundless and silent, or only babbling fables and pretences.

properties.title: The Polygon
properties.body:
From The Last Man by Mary Shelley (1826)

Mary Shelley was the daughter of Mary Wollstonecraft, author of ‘A Vindication of the Rights of Women’, and the anarchist philosopher William Godwin. She was born in a house on this site in 1797; 10 days after, Wollstonecraft died of septicaemia following an infection she developed in childbirth. Shelley is now best known for her novel Frankenstein; however, her novel The Last Man, though overlooked (if not rejected) at the time of its publication, has striking contemporary resonances. The novel is a dystopian fiction set in late-21st century Britain, in which a plague has killed off most of the world’s population. It is presented, not as fiction, but as assembled from prophecies that Shelley claims to have found in the cave of the Cumaean Sybil; the ancient Greek prophetess whose temple was in Cumae, near Naples.

We had now to descend a steep and rugged path, which led us to the mouth of a cavern. The entrance was small, and we were obliged to crawl on our hands and knees for some distance. The air was damp and cold; but we were soon in a large chamber, where the light of day was admitted through a narrow aperture, which was overgrown with brambles. The walls were covered with moss, and the floor was strewed with leaves. We had not been long in this place before we heard a noise like the rustling of wings, and I felt a cold breath pass over my face. I turned to my companion, who was standing at the entrance, and saw that he was pale and trembling. He said that he had seen something move in the darkness, but I could see nothing. We sat down on the ground, and I took out my notebook to write down what I had seen.

a succession of these [passages], which our resolution alone permitted us to surmount, we arrived at a wide cavern with an arched dome-like roof. An aperture in the midst let in the light of heaven; but this was overgrown with brambles and underwood, which acted as a veil, obscuring the day, and giving a solemn religious hue to the apartment. It was spacious, and nearly circular, with a raised seat of stone, about the size of a Grecian couch, at one end. The only sign that life had been here, was the perfect snow-white skeleton of a goat, which had probably not perceived the opening as it grazed on the hill above, and had fallen headlong. Ages perhaps had elapsed since this catastrophe; and the ruin it had made above, had been repaired by the growth of vegetation during many hundred summers.

At length my friend, who had taken up some of the leaves strewed about, exclaimed, "This is the Sibyl's cave; these are Sibylline leaves." On examination, we found that all the leaves, bark, and other substances were traced with written characters. What appeared to use more astonishing, was that these writing were expressed in various languages: some unknown to my companion, ancient Chaldee, and Egyptian hieroglyphics, as old as the Pyramids. Stranger still, some were in modern dialects, English and Italian. We could make out little by the dim light, but they seemed to contain prophecies, detailed relations of events but lately passed; names, now well known, but of modern date; and often exclamations of exultation or woe, of victory or defeat, were traced on their thin scant pages.

[…]

I present the public with my latest discoveries in the slight Sibylline pages. Scattered and unconnected as they are, I have been obliged to add links, and model the work into a consistent form. But the main substance rests on the truths contained in these poetic rhapsodies, and the divine intuitions which the Cumaean damsel obtained from heaven.

properties.title: St Pancras Old Church
properties.body:
From Vale Royal by Aidan Dun (1995)

St Pancras Old Church is supposedly one of the oldest sites of Christian worship in Britain, though the building now here was constructed in the 19th Century. There are lots of famous associations with the church yard. Mary Wollstonecraft and William Godwin were buried here; Mary Shelley planned her elopement with Percy Shelley at her mother’s grave. The collector and antiquarian John Soan is buried here in a tomb whose design influenced that of the red telephone box. Behind the church is the remains of the Hardy Tree, a tree encircled by gravestones which mark which were moved from part of the churchyard during the construction of the midland railway, a project overseen by the poet and novelist Thomas Hardy. The tree fell in 2022.

Long before the redevelopment of Kings Cross and St Pancras, the poet Aidan Dun composed Vale Royal, an epic poem which is both a mythic history of the area, and a prediction that it might in future be the heart of a spiritual renewal of Britain. You’ll notice that the church is slightly elevated from the surrounding ground and that the road curves. If it weren’t culverted, we would be on the banks of the River Fleet. As well as being a street just to the north of Kings Cross, the Vale Royal of the title is the river valley itself.

Between High chimneyed Bloomsbury
and the sloping squares of Camden town
there lies a great margin of many hundred Acres
It is a lost world of Meadows gone to seed
of rundown farms and wild Orchards
The Woodland Earth of foxes and paradise of hawks
Here are strange ruins
Brick fields and burning grounds
The Thorn Apple sways white trumpets in the summer
Herb Mercury stands in the shade of old walls
this whole region is circled widely at night
the living go over its borders to a country far beyond
Travelers lose their way on vague lanes
thickets of willow stand along the Fleet River
or shroud the unexpected Pond
Great assemblies of the mysterious Elm gesticulate under the Stars
these are dim layers of the highway man, see he waits with a flint lock loaded and primed
the wild beast of these Suburban woods
And in these nights so Ghostly and remote
the longtime derelict Church of Old St Pancras draws the outlaw to it by
the magnet of Shadows

properties.title: The Glass Bar
properties.body:
From Cruising Utopia by José Esteban Muñoz

The Glass Bar was women-only bar that was established by Elaine McKenzie and operated between 1995-2008 from a building called the West Lodge, which is now inhabited by the Euston Tap. This is one of two Portland stone lodges, built in a monumental neoclassical style, designed by the engineer J. B. Stansby in 1870. They are now Grade-II listed and are the only buildings to survive the controversial demolition of old Euston Station in the 1960s. The Glass Bar’s tenure in the West Lodge made it both ‘the most architecturally recognized queer venue in London and one of the most discrete, hidden in plain sight within the urban fabric’. McKenzie had found London’s queer venues to be dominated by white lesbian and gay people, and as a result - in her words - ‘cold and cliquey’; she’s recounted that as ‘a black gay person you had parties in odd places’. She wanted to provide a welcoming space for all women. Reflecting the West Lodge’s proximity to the universities of Bloomsbury, McKenzie’s 1995 planning application to Camden Council proposed a change of use from an office ‘to a meeting place and networking venue’ for ‘academic and professional women’. The membership model and £1 joining fee enabled McKenzie to prioritise women’s access. Her policy was, she says, ‘if you identified as a woman, that’s it you could come […] so we had cis and trans women in’. Despite striving to uphold an inclusive atmosphere, McKenzie herself experienced racist behaviour, such as being challenged about how she funded the bar, or being talked over, when white customers chose to address her white staff members. The Glass Bar was Tardis-like, bigger than it appeared from the outside, with an upstairs room and ground floor bar, linked by a spiral staircase. The bar offered a meeting place for women’s social networks, including ‘Kiss’, a group for queer Asian women.

Queerness is not yet here. Queerness is an ideality. Put another way, we are not yet queer, but we can feel it as the warm illumination of a horizon imbued with potentiality. We have never been queer, yet queerness exists for us as an ideality that can be distilled from the past and used to imagine a future. The future is queerness's domain.

[...]

The here and now is a prison house. We must strive, in the face of the here and now’s totalising rendering of reality, to think and feel a then and there. Some will say that all we have are the pleasures of this moment, but we must never settle for that minimal transport; we must dream and enact new and better pleasures, other ways of being in the world, and ultimately new worlds.
